prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: With no statutory definition to reference, it is necessary to look to court decisions to determine what terminology has been used to describe confidential business information.

Historically, the judiciary has used a number of adjectives, most commonly “confidential”, “secret”, “private” and “restricted”, to describe the confidential element of protected business information. A further group of adjectives, such as “business”, “trade”, “commercial” and “industrial”, have been used to describe the business element of the information. The combination of these two concepts offers a basic and straightforward definition of the type of information that will be protected by the common law: information that provides a business advantage as a result of the fact that it is kept secret. This is true whether the information is tangible or intangible.[1] The adjective “business” has additional significance because it distinguishes information of a commercial nature from other types of “confidential information”. Historically, the term “confidential information” has often included information relating to privacy, personal interests and government secrets.

American authorities have tended to refer to all confidential business information as “trade secrets”, even though much of the information now protected goes beyond original and more restrictive definitions of trade secrets. There is little doubt that the codification of that phrase in the uniform American legislation has encouraged more consistent usage. While Canadian and English authorities have both made significant use of the term “trade secret”, they have more frequently used terminology along the lines of “confidential information”, “breach of confidence” and “commercial confidences”.

For our purposes, the terms “confidential business information” and “trade secrets” will be treated as synonymous,[2] despite the fact that “trade secret” has sometimes been treated as a narrower term of art, even a subset of the more generic terminology “confidential business information”.[3] For the sake of simplicity, we will treat both terms as inclusive of all business information of a confidential character that is capable of being protected under present Canadian legal principles.
S.R. Metal Impregnation (Ontario) Ltd. v. C & C Coatings Ltd. (1997), 77 C.P.R. (3d) 443 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)).

See Shaw v. Shaw (2007), 162 A.C.W.S. (3d) 571 (Ont. S.C.J.), wherein a protective order applied to confidential information where the information was confidential and commercially sensitive and a competitor could obtain an unfair advantage if the information were released.

Historically, the only area of law where the distinction appears to have had any practical impact is that of employment law, where an employee, after departing from an employment relationship, would normally be prevented from using trade secrets but is left free to make use of other business information.
